elements.content: Two new Wells–Dawson polyoxometalate-based metal–organic frameworks (POMOFs) with different helical channels were synthesized depending on the self-adaptive coordination nature of P2W18 polyanion. The hemispherical coordination of P2W18 clusters with Ag under the help of 1,2,4-triazole ligand induces the isolation of the twofold helical channels-containing POMOF 1, while the clockwise coordination of P2W18 clusters with Cu results in the fourfold helical channels-containing POMOF 2. Both compounds exhibit good electrochemical performance as lithium-ion batteries electrode materials due to their excellent redox properties and structural stabilization. The long-term cycling capacity as demonstrated by the still above 400–450 mA h g–1 for 350 cycles at the current density of 100 mA g–1 reveals the important role of the helical channels within exposed P2W18 polyanions in 1 and 2, which allow the relatively easy Li+ deintercalation/intercalation. To illustrate the lithium storage, the impedance spectra of compound 2 during the first and 350th charge process was also studied for the first time.

elements.content: New Wells−Dawson polyoxometalate-based metal−organic frameworks (POMOFs) with different helical channels constructed by means of the self-adaptive coordination nature of P2W18 cluster exhibit good electrochemical performance as anode materials in LIBs.
elements.clean_text: New Wells-Dawson polyoxometalate-based metal-organic frameworks (POMOFs) with different helical channels constructed by means of the self-adaptive coordination nature of P2W18 cluster exhibit good electrochemical performance as anode materials in LIBs.

elements.content: The increasing interest in metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) containing helix has been justified by not only their potential application as functional materials but also their particular beauty and intriguing structural diversities. Polyoxometalates (POMs), a subset of inorganic clusters with a wide range of application potentials associated with their versatile structure and oxygen-rich surface, have also been fabricated into POM-based MOFs (POMOFs), in particular, those containing helix. Interestingly, by means of their self-adaptive coordination nature, POMs can automatically regulate the coordination sites based on different surrounding situation, which facilitates the construction of diverse helical configuration. As expected, the nature of metal ions and organic ligands can greatly influence the self-adaptive abilities of POMs, resulting in different helical POMOFs. In other words, construction of a metal ion transportation system is advantageous and necessary for the successful self-adaptive coordination of POMs. Because of the versatile coordination modes and smaller steric hindrance, (Scheme S1, Supporting Information), triazole molecule containing three N-donors is easy to construct the metal ion transportation system. This, in combination with the multiple flexible V-shaped coordination modes of POMs, which may respond to the metal ion transportation system in a rapid manner, renders the easy the formation of helical POMOFs. More importantly, in comparison with the Keggin POMs possessing T d space symmetry and 24 coordination oxygen atoms, Wells–Dawson POMs with the lower space symmetry of D 3h and more coordination oxygen atoms of 54 are of more flexible and free self-adaptive coordination nature, which are therefore expected to result in new POMOFs with diverse structures and functionalities. However, the Wells–Dawson POMs-based POMOFs still remain rare. As a consequence, constructing Wells–Dawson POMs-based POMOFs still remains highly desirable for chemists and material scientists.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

The increasing interest in metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) containing helix has been justified by not only their potential application as functional materials but also their particular beauty and intriguing structural diversities. Polyoxometalates (POMs), a subset of inorganic clusters with a wide range of application potentials associated with their versatile structure and oxygen-rich surface, have also been fabricated into POM-based MOFs (POMOFs), in particular, those containing helix. Interestingly, by means of their self-adaptive coordination nature, POMs can automatically regulate the coordination sites based on different surrounding situation, which facilitates the construction of diverse helical configuration. As expected, the nature of metal ions and organic ligands can greatly influence the self-adaptive abilities of POMs, resulting in different helical POMOFs. In other words, construction of a metal ion transportation system is advantageous and necessary for the successful self-adaptive coordination of POMs. Because of the versatile coordination modes and smaller steric hindrance, (Scheme S1, Supporting Information), triazole molecule containing three N-donors is easy to construct the metal ion transportation system. This, in combination with the multiple flexible V-shaped coordination modes of POMs, which may respond to the metal ion transportation system in a rapid manner, renders the easy the formation of helical POMOFs. More importantly, in comparison with the Keggin POMs possessing T  d  space symmetry and 24 coordination oxygen atoms, Wells-Dawson POMs with the lower space symmetry of D 3h  and more coordination oxygen atoms of 54 are of more flexible and free self-adaptive coordination nature, which are therefore expected to result in new POMOFs with diverse structures and functionalities. However, the Wells-Dawson POMs-based POMOFs still remain rare. As a consequence, constructing Wells-Dawson POMs-based POMOFs still remains highly desirable for chemists and material scientists.

elements.content: On the one hand, lithium ion batteries (LIBs) have been deemed as one of effective energy storage systems with great application potential due to their high energy density, long lifespan, and remarkable rate capability. On the other hand, some technological puzzles such as their low specific capacity and safety problems still remain unresolved. POMs as an “electron sponge” usually exhibit good capacity during the lithiation process in LIBs because of their multielectron reversible transfer nature. However, their practical application in LIBs was retarded by their intrinsic low electronic conductivity together with some degree of solubility in electrolyte. As a consequence, fabricating POMs into MOFs appears to be a good method toward optimizing their LIBs performance through improving the electronic conductivity, lowering the solubility in electrolyte, and increasing the structural stability. In the present work, unprecedented Wells–Dawson POM-based POMOFs with different helix H5[Ag9(trz)8]­[P2W18O62]·2H2O (1) and [Cu8(trz)6(OH)4(H2O)5]­[P2W18O62]·2H2O (2) were successfully fabricated from the Wells–Dawson POMs as self-adaptive blocks and metal ions transportation system constructed from 1,2,4-triazole (trz) organic molecules and Ag/Cu ions. In particular, these crystalline compounds as anode materials for LIBs showed remarkable high specific capacity and long-term cycling stability, indicating their great potential application in LIBs.

elements.content: The structure features of 1 and 2 were revealed by single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns, Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectra, thermogravimetric analysis (TGA), and elemental analyses were measured on Siemens D5005 diffractometer (Cu Kα (λ = 1.5418 Å) radiation), Alpha Centaurt FT/IR spectrophotometer (KBr pellets), PerkinElmer TG-7 analyzer, and PerkinElmer 240C elemental analyzer, respectively. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analyses were performed on thermo ESCALAB 250 spectrometer with a Mg Kα achromatic X-ray source. The Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) surface area (SBET) was measured by N2 adsorption technique at 77 K using a QuadraSorb SI surface area analyzer.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and General methods

The structure features of 1 and 2 were revealed by single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns, Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectra, thermogravimetric analysis (TGA), and elemental analyses were measured on Siemens D5005 diffractometer (Cu Kα (λ = 1.5418 Å) radiation), Alpha Centaurt FT/IR spectrophotometer (KBr pellets), PerkinElmer TG-7 analyzer, and PerkinElmer 240C elemental analyzer, respectively. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analyses were performed on thermo ESCALAB 250 spectrometer with a Mg Kα achromatic X-ray source. The Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) surface area (SBET) was measured by N2 adsorption technique at 77 K using a QuadraSorb SI surface area analyzer.

elements.content: The mixture of K6P2W18O62 (300 mg, 0.07 mmol), AgNO3 (150 mg, 0.88 mmol), trz (60 mg, 0.86 mmol), and NH4VO3 (36 mg, 0.31 mmol) was added into 10 mL of H2O, which was stirred for 1 h in air. The pH value was adjusted to 3 by 1 M HCl. The resulting mixture was sealed in a 20 mL Teflon-lined reactor and kept at 180 °C for 3 d. After it cooled to room temperature, the yellow block crystals of 1 were isolated, washed with water, and dried at room temperature. Yield: 63% based on W. Anal. Calcd for C16N24H20Ag9P2W18O64 (5914.3): C 3.25, H 0.34, N 5.68%. Found: C 3.21, H 0.56, N 5.66%.

elements.content: Single-crystal X-ray diffraction data for 1 and 2 were studied on a Bruker Apex CCD II area-detector diffractometer with graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.710 73 Å) at 296(2) K. Absorption corrections were applied using multiscan technique and conducted by using the SADABS program. The structure was solved by the direct method and refined full-matrix least squares on F 2 through the SHELXTL and OLEX2 software package. The numbers of lattice H2O molecules and counter cations for 1 and 2 were evaluated by the results of elemental analyses, TG curves, and calculations of electron count in the voids with SQUEEZE. Crystal data and structure refinement for 1 and 2 are listed in , and the selected bond lengths and angles of compounds are listed in Tables S1 and S2 (Supporting Information).
elements.clean_text:
X-ray Crystallographic Study

Single-crystal X-ray diffraction data for 1 and 2 were studied on a Bruker Apex CCD II area-detector diffractometer with graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) at 296(2) K. Absorption corrections were applied using multiscan technique and conducted by using the SADABS program. The structure was solved by the direct method and refined full-matrix least squares on F 2 through the SHELXTL and OLEX2 software package. The numbers of lattice H2O molecules and counter cations for 1 and 2 were evaluated by the results of elemental analyses, TG curves, and calculations of electron count in the voids with SQUEEZE. Crystal data and structure refinement for 1 and 2 are listed in , and the selected bond lengths and angles of compounds are listed in Tables S1 and S2 (Supporting Information).

The crystal water molecules of 1 and 2 were removed under 100 °C in vacuum oven before they were used as electrode materials. The working electrode was prepared by casting a slurry of compound 1/2, super-P carbon, and poly­(vinylidene fluoride) (PVDF) at a weight ratio of 7:2:1 on pure Cu foil, then being dried in vacuum at 50 °C for 24 h. The active anode material loading mass is ca. 2 mg cm–2. Button cell was assembled with the working electrode, Li counter electrode, and 1.0 M LiPF6 in ethylene carbonate (EC)/diethyl carbonate (DEC) (1:1 v/v) as the electrolyte. Galvanostatic charge/discharge cycles were performed on a LAND 2001A instrument. Cyclic voltammetry (CV) and electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) were performed on an electrochemical workstation CHI750D and Princeton Applied Research, respectively.
elements.clean_text:
Electrochemistry

The crystal water molecules of 1 and 2 were removed under 100 °C in vacuum oven before they were used as electrode materials. The working electrode was prepared by casting a slurry of compound 1/2, super-P carbon, and poly(vinylidene fluoride) (PVDF) at a weight ratio of 7:2:1 on pure Cu foil, then being dried in vacuum at 50 °C for 24 h. The active anode material loading mass is ca. 2 mg cm-2. Button cell was assembled with the working electrode, Li counter electrode, and 1.0 M LiPF6 in ethylene carbonate (EC)/diethyl carbonate (DEC) (1:1 v/v) as the electrolyte. Galvanostatic charge/discharge cycles were performed on a LAND 2001A instrument. Cyclic voltammetry (CV) and electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) were performed on an electrochemical workstation CHI750D and Princeton Applied Research, respectively.

elements.content: The oxidation states of all the tungsten atoms (+VI), Ag atoms (+I), and Cu atoms (+II) in both compounds were confirmed by valence sum calculations (S = exp­[∑−(R – R o)/B] (S = bond valence, R = bond length) as well as the XPS analysis. Single-crystal data reveal that 1 crystallizes in the orthorhombic space group C2221 and consists of one [P2W18O62]6– polyanion (abbreviate to P2W18), six Ag+ ions, and eight trz ligands (Figure S1 in the Supporting Information). Compound 2 crystallizes in the monoclinic space group P21/c, and the crystallographic unit contains 2 unique P2W18 polyanions, 11 Cu2+ ions, and 7 trz ligands.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

The oxidation states of all the tungsten atoms (+VI), Ag atoms (+I), and Cu atoms (+II) in both compounds were confirmed by valence sum calculations (S = exp[∑-(R - R o)/B] (S = bond valence, R = bond length) as well as the XPS analysis. Single-crystal data reveal that 1 crystallizes in the orthorhombic space group C2221 and consists of one [P2W18O62]6- polyanion (abbreviate to P2W18), six Ag+ ions, and eight trz ligands (Figure S1 in the Supporting Information). Compound 2 crystallizes in the monoclinic space group P21/c, and the crystallographic unit contains 2 unique P2W18 polyanions, 11 Cu2+ ions, and 7 trz ligands.

elements.content: In compound 1, there are five crystallographic independent Ag ions, among which Ag1, Ag2, Ag3, and Ag5 ions adopt bidentate linear coordination mode, and Ag4 ion exhibits “Y-shape” geometry coordination. Five unique trz ligands display five kinds of linking patterns with different Ag+ ions (Figure S2 in the Supporting Information). As a result, each P2W18 polyanion connects eight Ag+ ions, namely, two Ag1, two Ag2, and four Ag3 ions. The bond lengths around the Ag+ ions are in the normal range of 1.983–2.670 Å (Ag–N) and 2.350–2.782 Å (Ag–O). Compound 1 exhibits a three-dimensional (3D) framework containing one kind of twofold helix along a axis. More specifically, the left-handed helices follow the route of {Ag3-P2W18-Ag3-trz-Ag4-trz-Ag2-trz-Ag3-P2W18-Ag3-trz-Ag4-trz-Ag2-trz-Ag3} n , . Then the left-handed helices extend into the homological helical layer via the Ag3–P2W18–Ag3 fragments (Figure S3a in the Supporting Information). Similarly, the arrangement mode as well as the composition of right-handed helix is exactly the same as the left-handed helix (Figure S3b in the Supporting Information). The left- and right-handed helices with the same thread pitch of 14.67 Å compose the double helix by sharing P2W18 polyanions. Finally, these double helices generate an infinite 3D framework by partially sharing building blocks. There is 461.1 Å3 potential solvent area volume (5.8% per unit cell) calculated by PLATON routine. If P2W18 polyanion, Ag3, and Ag4 ions can be taken as a four-connected node, the whole network can be resembled as a three-nodal net with the point symbol of {42·84} (Figure S4a in the Supporting Information).

elements.content: In compound 2, Cu1, Cu4, and Cu8 ions adopt the tridentate “T-shape” coordination modes, while Cu3 and Cu5 ions take the cruciform coordination modes, and Cu2, Cu6, and Cu7 ions employ the tetradentate “seesaw” coordination (Figure S5 in the Supporting Information). Six kinds of trz molecules exhibit the same linking patterns but with different Cu2+ ions. All the Cu–N bonds (2.03–2.27 Å) and Cu–O bonds (2.19–2.6 Å) are under the normal ranges. In the absence of P2W18 polyanions, Cu2+ ions and trz ligands form a metal–organic framework with fourfold helix, . Especially, three trz ligands connect the three Cu2+ ions (Cu1, Cu2, and Cu8) to form the organic–metal secondary building unit (represented as SBU1) and with Cu3, Cu5, and Cu7 ions to form the secondary building unit SBU2. Then SBUs are linked together via Cu4 and Cu6, forming the left- and right-handed helices in the same route of {SBU1-Cu4-SBU2-Cu6-SBU1-Cu6-SBU1-SBU2-Cu4-SBU1-Cu6-SBU1-SBU2-Cu6} n along a axis. Two independent left-handed or right-handed helices then arrange themselves into the homological double helices, respectively. Furthermore, the double-left-handed helices and double-right-handed helices fuse together into a fourfold meso-helical channel. Because all helices possess the same thread pitch of 36.97 Å, two adjacent fourfold helical channels intertwine together by cross-linking or adjoining connection (Figure S6 in the Supporting Information). Ultimately, fourfold helical channels constitute a unique (3,4,3)-connected MOF with an unprecedented {46·83·10}­{4·6·8}­{6·82} topology (Figure S4b in the Supporting Information). In simplification, Cu6 and SUB2 are the three-connected node, and SUB1 acts as the four-connected node.

elements.content: An interesting structural feature is the existence of another kind of helical channel in compound 2. In general, POMs are introduced into MOF either as templated guests or as part of MOF. It is worth noting that P2W18 polyanions as template in compound 2 are encapsulated within the cavities of MOF via covalent bond; meanwhile, P2W18 polyanions as building blocks participate in the construction of the helix. As can be seen in , P2W18 polyanions, trz ligands, and Cu2+ ions (Cu5, Cu6, Cu7, and Cu8) form two kinds of meso-helical channels, namely, Type-I channel and Type-II channel. Type-I meso-helical channel is composed of Type-I left-handed and right-handed helices following the same route of {Cu6-trz-Cu7-P2W18-Cu6-trz-Cu8-trz-Cu6-trz-Cu7-P2W18-Cu6-trz-Cu5-P2W18-Cu6} n along a axis. In a similar manner, Type-II meso-helical channel consists of Type-II left-handed and right-handed helixes. However, because of the different coordinated bonds formed between P2W18 polyanions and Cu2+ ions from those formed between the trz ligands and Cu2+ ions, two kinds of helical channels possess disparate size, even though they obey the same trajectory. As a whole, from the view of topology, the network of compound 2 can be resembled as (4, 5, 3)-connected 3D framework with an unprecedented {3·4·6·73·84}­{3·4·6·73}­{3·6·7} topology, in which the four-connected nodes are POM polyanions, the five-connected nodes are Cu6 ions, and the three-connected nodes are Cu8 ions (Figure S4c in the Supporting Information). There is 2798.3 Å3 potential solvent area volume (31% per unit cell) calculated by PLATON routine.
elements.clean_text: An interesting structural feature is the existence of another kind of helical channel in compound 2. In general, POMs are introduced into MOF either as templated guests or as part of MOF. It is worth noting that P2W18 polyanions as template in compound 2 are encapsulated within the cavities of MOF via covalent bond; meanwhile, P2W18 polyanions as building blocks participate in the construction of the helix. As can be seen in , P2W18 polyanions, trz ligands, and Cu2+ ions (Cu5, Cu6, Cu7, and Cu8) form two kinds of meso-helical channels, namely, Type-I channel and Type-II channel. Type-I meso-helical channel is composed of Type-I left-handed and right-handed helices following the same route of {Cu6-trz-Cu7-P2W18-Cu6-trz-Cu8-trz-Cu6-trz-Cu7-P2W18-Cu6-trz-Cu5-P2W18-Cu6} n  along a axis. In a similar manner, Type-II meso-helical channel consists of Type-II left-handed and right-handed helixes. However, because of the different coordinated bonds formed between P2W18 polyanions and Cu2+ ions from those formed between the trz ligands and Cu2+ ions, two kinds of helical channels possess disparate size, even though they obey the same trajectory. As a whole, from the view of topology, the network of compound 2 can be resembled as (4, 5, 3)-connected 3D framework with an unprecedented {3⋅4⋅6⋅73⋅84}{3⋅4⋅6⋅73}{3⋅6⋅7} topology, in which the four-connected nodes are POM polyanions, the five-connected nodes are Cu6 ions, and the three-connected nodes are Cu8 ions (Figure S4c in the Supporting Information). There is 2798.3 Å3 potential solvent area volume (31% per unit cell) calculated by PLATON routine.

elements.content: At the end of this section, the self-adaptive coordination abilities of P2W18 polyanions should be emphasized and discussed. Unlike compound 1, the helices exist in both MOF and POMOF framework in compound 2, , which can be explained by the stimulus of metal ions. It is well-known that activating all 18 terminal oxygen atoms and 36 bridging μ2-O atoms of P2W18 polyanion is out of the question, but P2W18 polyanions can adopt the most appropriate coordination pattern based on the self-adaptive coordination ability under diverse inducement factor. As detailed in the structural description, P2W18 polyanions in compound 1 adopt hemispherical coordination mode, forming the P2W18-Ag-trz type helix. However, in compound 2 the P2W18 polyanions inundated with Cu2+ ions display clockwise coordination mode, which are further arranged into metal–organic helix and P2W18-Cu-trz helix. The remarkable fact is that P2W18 polyanions in compound 2 are encapsulated in the helical channels instead of being a part of helix as in compound 1. This might promote the intercalation and storage of Li+ on account of the exposed P2W18 polyanions in the helical channels.

elements.content: The XPS (Figures S7 and S8 in the Supporting Information) of 1 and 2 shows two peaks at 35.7 eV of WVI4f7/2 and 37.6 eV of WVI4f5/2, which indicates that the oxidation states of all tungsten atoms are +VI. In addition, the peaks at 374.1 and 368.2 eV can be attributed to AgI3d3/2 and AgI3d5/2 in 1, and the peaks at 954.5 and 934.7 eV can be attributed to CuII2p1/2 and CuII2p3/2 in 2, suggesting the oxidation states of Ag ions and Cu ions are +I and +II, respectively. As shown in Figure S9 (Supporting Information), the TG analysis of 1 and 2 indicates that the weight loss before 200 °C is water molecules, and the whole framework completely gets collapsed after 320 °C. The experimental PXRD patterns of 1 and 2 (Figure S10 in the Supporting Information) are consistent with simulated ones, except for a little difference in reflection intensities, indicating their phase purity. FT/IR spectra are shown in Figure S11 (Supporting Information). The vibration peaks at 1092, 960, 913, and 789 cm–1, for 1, and at 1091, 953, 913, and 789 cm–1 for 2 are assigned to the νas (P–O), νas (O–W), νas (W–Ob–W), and νas (W–Oc–W) vibrations. The characteristic peaks between 1627 and 1162 cm–1 are assigned to the trz ligand vibrations. The surface area was measured by BET (Figure S12, Supporting Information), giving a surface area of 2.45 m2 g–1 with the pore size mainly distributed in the range of 1.64–3.57 nm on the basis of the density functional theory (DFT) investigation. The result suggests the presence of microporous structure in POMOF 2.
elements.clean_text:
XPS, TG, FT/IR, PXRD, and BET Analyses

The XPS (Figures S7 and S8 in the Supporting Information) of 1 and 2 shows two peaks at 35.7 eV of WVI4f7/2 and 37.6 eV of WVI4f5/2, which indicates that the oxidation states of all tungsten atoms are +VI. In addition, the peaks at 374.1 and 368.2 eV can be attributed to AgI3d3/2 and AgI3d5/2 in 1, and the peaks at 954.5 and 934.7 eV can be attributed to CuII2p1/2 and CuII2p3/2 in 2, suggesting the oxidation states of Ag ions and Cu ions are +I and +II, respectively. As shown in Figure S9 (Supporting Information), the TG analysis of 1 and 2 indicates that the weight loss before 200 °C is water molecules, and the whole framework completely gets collapsed after 320 °C. The experimental PXRD patterns of 1 and 2 (Figure S10 in the Supporting Information) are consistent with simulated ones, except for a little difference in reflection intensities, indicating their phase purity. FT/IR spectra are shown in Figure S11 (Supporting Information). The vibration peaks at 1092, 960, 913, and 789 cm-1, for 1, and at 1091, 953, 913, and 789 cm-1 for 2 are assigned to the νas (P-O), νas (O-W), νas (W-Ob-W), and νas (W-Oc-W) vibrations. The characteristic peaks between 1627 and 1162 cm-1 are assigned to the trz ligand vibrations. The surface area was measured by BET (Figure S12, Supporting Information), giving a surface area of 2.45 m2 g-1 with the pore size mainly distributed in the range of 1.64-3.57 nm on the basis of the density functional theory (DFT) investigation. The result suggests the presence of microporous structure in POMOF 2.

elements.content: The electrochemical performances of 1 and 2 as electrode materials were evaluated by incorporating them into coin-type half cells in the potential window between 0.01 and 3.0 V versus Li+/Li. Prior to this, the stability of both compounds under different acidity, temperature, and electrolyte were tested via FT-IR spectra (Figure S11 in the Supporting Information). The results confirm that both 1 and 2 possess outstanding structural stability. The first discharge capacity of 1 and 2 amounts to 975 and 1122 mA h g–1, respectively, a,b, which drops to 617 and 530 mA h g–1 in the next cycle. The dramatic reduction of capacity after the first cycle is caused by the formation of the solid electrolyte interphase (SEI) films. As shown in c,d, the cycling capacity of compound 2 maintains stable above 430 mA h g–1 for 100 cycles at the current density of 100 mA g–1. This, however, is not the case for compound 1, which can only stay around 320 mA h g–1 after 100 cycles. In addition, the Coulombic efficiency of both 1 and 2 can reach a plateau at 99% after 20 to 30 cycles, demonstrating their commendable cycling stability.
elements.clean_text:
Electrochemical Performances

The electrochemical performances of 1 and 2 as electrode materials were evaluated by incorporating them into coin-type half cells in the potential window between 0.01 and 3.0 V versus Li+/Li. Prior to this, the stability of both compounds under different acidity, temperature, and electrolyte were tested via FT-IR spectra (Figure S11 in the Supporting Information). The results confirm that both 1 and 2 possess outstanding structural stability. The first discharge capacity of 1 and 2 amounts to 975 and 1122 mA h g-1, respectively, a,b, which drops to 617 and 530 mA h g-1 in the next cycle. The dramatic reduction of capacity after the first cycle is caused by the formation of the solid electrolyte interphase (SEI) films. As shown in c,d, the cycling capacity of compound 2 maintains stable above 430 mA h g-1 for 100 cycles at the current density of 100 mA g-1. This, however, is not the case for compound 1, which can only stay around 320 mA h g-1 after 100 cycles. In addition, the Coulombic efficiency of both 1 and 2 can reach a plateau at 99% after 20 to 30 cycles, demonstrating their commendable cycling stability.

elements.clean_text: 5  (a, b) Galvanostatic charge-discharge curves of compounds 1 and 2 before 50th cycles at a current density 100 mA g-1. (c, d) The charge-discharge capacity and the Coulombic efficiency of compounds 1 and 2 during 100 cycles at a current density of 100 mA g-1.

elements.content: Normally, cycling and rate performance of LIBs are the important assessment criteria for commercialized applications. It is noteworthy that compounds 1 and 2 display good rate performance and cycling stability at the current densities from 100 to 1000 mA g–1, a. The reversible capacities of 1 and 2 at 100 mA g–1 are 450 and 380 mA h g–1, respectively, after an initial drop. When the current densities become 1 A g–1, the capacities of 1 and 2 can maintain at 150 and 120 mA h g–1, respectively. It is worth noting that, when the current density has been reset back to 100 mA g–1, the specific capacities of 1 and 2 restored almost to the original state. These results indicate that the helical structure in these novel POMOFs favors promoting the electrochemical performance to LIBs. In addition, the discharge capacities of 1 and 2 exhibit an upward trend in the subsequent cycles. On one hand, the activation phenomenon may be attributed to the sluggish forming process of the SEI films. On the other hand, we suspect that Li+ hardly accesses the interior P2W18 polyanions of helical channel at the early stage. Unambiguously, it should take some time for Li+ to completely arrive at the W atoms sites of P2W18 polyanions. As a consequence, 1 shows little difference from 2 in the cycling capacity and rate performance at the first 100th cycles. However, after the 100th cycle, the discharge capacities of 2 take a steady rise, while the discharge capacities of 1 exhibit a fluctuation. After 350 cycles, the capacity retention ratio of 2 is 50%, while only 34% of the capacity is maintained for 1. These results reveal that the helical channels encapsulating P2W18 polyanions can allow the Li+ ions relatively easily access, showing the advantage in terms of Li+ storage.

elements.content: Cyclic voltammograms (CV) of 1 and 2 were recorded at the range of 0.01–3 V with the scan rate of 0.1 mV s–1, a. The irreversible reduction peak appearing at ∼0.7 V at the first cycle, which gets disappeared in the subsequent cycles, should be due to the formation of the SEI films. The Li+ insertion procedure induces a reduction peak at 0.01–0.2 V (Figure S13, Supporting Information). In addition, EIS was used to study the dynamics performance of compounds 1 and 2 as anode materials for LIBs, b. As a rule, the high-to-middle frequency semicircle represents the electrolyte resistance, SEI film resistance, and the charge-transfer resistance, respectively, and the Warburg impedance (Z w) represents the diffusion of Li+ ions into the bulk electrode. The R values are 240 Ω for 1 and 200 Ω for 2, indicating the good electrochemical kinetics and fast transmission pathway for Li+ ions due to the helical channels in both POMOFs.

elements.content: To illustrate the electrochemical behavior of the POMOFs cell, the impedance spectra of 2 electrode during the first discharge–charge process were studied at various open-circuit voltages (OCV). As shown in , the fresh cell displays smaller impedance (ca. 80 Ω) than that of static placement for 10 h (ca. 210 Ω) due to the formation of stable SEI film on the surface of electrode. During the first discharge to 0.01 V, when discharge current passes through the cell, the SEI film is damaged by oxidation of the lithium–metal electrode, resulting in the drop immediately in the impedance as indicated by the shrinkage of the semicircle diameter. In the subsequent charging process from 0.01 to 3 V, the large semicircle at high-to-middle frequency, a passivated film impedance, gets increased to the original state, indicating the slow recombination of the SEI film. It is noteworthy that the apparent capacity resistance can be observed at low voltage due to the accumulation of Li+ ions in the electrode. We suspect that the Li+ is hardly able to access the interior of helical channel at the beginning due to the nanopore sizes of crystalline POMOFs materials. When the charge reaches the high voltage, the capacity resistance disappears, revealing the pseudocapacitance mechanism for lithium storage in initial charge–discharge process.

elements.content: To further investigate the lithium storage behavior in POMOF electrode, the Nyquist plots of 350th cycles at the potential from 0.01 to 3 V is explored, . In contrast to the impedance spectra at the first charge, the curve shape of the high-to-middle frequency region is hardly changed under different OCVs, suggesting the stability of the battery internal structure. However, the arc curve of the low frequency (the capacitance impedance) gets nearly disappeared even at low voltage due to the activation of the Li+ insertion sites of POMOF electrode. This result indicates that the Li+ ions accumulating on the surface of the active material are broken into the new resistance, suggesting the change of the capacitive effect to the diffusion of lithium ions in the POMOF materials. On the basis of the above-mentioned results, we speculate that combination of the slow recombination of the SEI film with the inactivated lithium storage sites results in the pseudocapacitance mechanism in the initial cycles. However, after that the formation of the stable SEI film can prevent the electrolyte from decomposing on the surface of the electrode. This, in combination with the activation of Li insertion sites of POMOF electrode, results in the stable charge–discharge cycles.

elements.content: In summary, by utilizing the self-adaptive coordination nature of P2W18 cluster, two Wells–Dawson-type POMs-based hybrid compounds containing different helical channels have been successfully synthesized, paving the way for exploring their application-driven functional studies. Their application as anode materials for LIBs exhibits good discharge capacity together with the long-term cycling stabilization due to the stable charge transmission channels provided by the helical structures. In particular, the helical channels encapsulating P2W18 polyanions in the Cu-involved POMOF allow the Li+ ions to easily access and therefore make additional contribution to its good electrochemical performance in LIBs. The present result should be helpful for the design and synthesis of new POMOFs with intriguing structure and superior electrochemical performance.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In summary, by utilizing the self-adaptive coordination nature of P2W18 cluster, two Wells-Dawson-type POMs-based hybrid compounds containing different helical channels have been successfully synthesized, paving the way for exploring their application-driven functional studies. Their application as anode materials for LIBs exhibits good discharge capacity together with the long-term cycling stabilization due to the stable charge transmission channels provided by the helical structures. In particular, the helical channels encapsulating P2W18 polyanions in the Cu-involved POMOF allow the Li+ ions to easily access and therefore make additional contribution to its good electrochemical performance in LIBs. The present result should be helpful for the design and synthesis of new POMOFs with intriguing structure and superior electrochemical performance.

cln_elements.content:
The mixture of K6P2W18O62 (300 mg, 0.07 mmol), AgNO3 (150 mg, 0.88 mmol), trz (60 mg, 0.86 mmol), and NH4VO3 (36 mg, 0.31 mmol) was added into 10 mL of H2O, which was stirred for 1 h in air. The pH value was adjusted to 3 by 1 M HCl. The resulting mixture was sealed in a 20 mL Teflon-lined reactor and kept at 180 °C for 3 d. After it cooled to room temperature, the yellow block crystals of 1 were isolated, washed with water, and dried at room temperature. Yield: 63% based on W. Anal. Calcd for C16N24H20Ag9P2W18O64 (5914.3): C 3.25, H 0.34, N 5.68%. Found: C 3.21, H 0.56, N 5.66%.

The pH value was adjusted to 3 by 1 M HCl. The resulting mixture was sealed in a 20 mL Teflon-lined reactor and kept at 180 °C for 3 d. After it cooled to room temperature, the green block crystals of 2 were isolated, washed with water, and dried at room temperature. Yield: 60% based on W. Anal. Calcd for C12N18H24Cu8P2W18O73 (5468.01): C, 2.63; H, 0.44; N, 4.61%. Found: C, 2.64; H, 0.45; N, 4.57%.

cln_elements.content:
The XPS (Figures S7 and S8 in the Supporting Information) of 1 and 2 shows two peaks at 35.7 eV of WVI4f7/2 and 37.6 eV of WVI4f5/2, which indicates that the oxidation states of all tungsten atoms are +VI. In addition, the peaks at 374.1 and 368.2 eV can be attributed to AgI3d3/2 and AgI3d5/2 in 1, and the peaks at 954.5 and 934.7 eV can be attributed to CuII2p1/2 and CuII2p3/2 in 2, suggesting the oxidation states of Ag ions and Cu ions are +I and +II, respectively. As shown in Figure S9 (Supporting Information), the TG analysis of 1 and 2 indicates that the weight loss before 200 °C is water molecules, and the whole framework completely gets collapsed after 320 °C. The experimental PXRD patterns of 1 and 2 (Figure S10 in the Supporting Information) are consistent with simulated ones, except for a little difference in reflection intensities, indicating their phase purity. FT/IR spectra are shown in Figure S11 (Supporting Information). The vibration peaks at 1092, 960, 913, and 789 cm–1, for 1, and at 1091, 953, 913, and 789 cm–1 for 2 are assigned to the νas (P–O), νas (O–W), νas (W–Ob–W), and νas (W–Oc–W) vibrations. The characteristic peaks between 1627 and 1162 cm–1 are assigned to the trz ligand vibrations. The surface area was measured by BET (Figure S12, Supporting Information), giving a surface area of 2.45 m2 g–1 with the pore size mainly distributed in the range of 1.64–3.57 nm on the basis of the density functional theory (DFT) investigation. The result suggests the presence of microporous structure in POMOF 2.

Electrochemical Performances

The electrochemical performances of 1 and 2 as electrode materials were evaluated by incorporating them into coin-type half cells in the potential window between 0.01 and 3.0 V versus Li+/Li. Prior to this, the stability of both compounds under different acidity, temperature, and electrolyte were tested via FT-IR spectra (Figure S11 in the Supporting Information). The results confirm that both 1 and 2 possess outstanding structural stability. The first discharge capacity of 1 and 2 amounts to 975 and 1122 mA h g–1, respectively, a,b, which drops to 617 and 530 mA h g–1 in the next cycle. The dramatic reduction of capacity after the first cycle is caused by the formation of the solid electrolyte interphase (SEI) films. As shown in c,d, the cycling capacity of compound 2 maintains stable above 430 mA h g–1 for 100 cycles at the current density of 100 mA g–1. This, however, is not the case for compound 1, which can only stay around 320 mA h g–1 after 100 cycles. In addition, the Coulombic efficiency of both 1 and 2 can reach a plateau at 99% after 20 to 30 cycles, demonstrating their commendable cycling stability.
